column1: Title: Medicaid and CHIP Income Eligibility Limits for Pregnant Women, 2003-2018 | The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation

Reflects highest eligibility limit for pregnant women under Medicaid, CHIP, or the unborn child option. For details on each of these eligibility limits, please visit: [http://kff.org/health-reform/state-indicator/medicaid-and-chip-income-eligibility-limits-for-pregnant-women-as-a-percent-of-the-federal-poverty-level/](http://kff.org/health-reform/state-indicator/medicaid-and-chip-income-eligibility-limits-for-pregnant-women-as-a-percent-of-the-federal-poverty-level/).

Changes over time reflect policy changes and, in some cases, changes in state reporting. Changes between January 2013 and 2014 reflect conversion to MAGI-based income eligibility standards. Some changes between January 2014 and January 2015 reflect continued adjustments to these MAGI conversions.
Beginning in 2014, income limits include a disregard equal to five percentage points of the FPL.
See annual survey reports for state-specific notes.

Based on a national survey conducted by the Kaiser Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured with the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, 2003-2009; and with the Georgetown University Center for Children and Families, 2011-2018. Available at: [http://kff.org/medicaid/report/annual-updates-on-eligibility-rules-enrollment-and/](http://kff.org/medicaid/report/annual-updates-on-eligibility-rules-enrollment-and/). For some states that have adopted the unborn child option, data for January 2014 are from MAGI-conversion plans available at [www.medicaid.gov](https://www.medicaid.gov/).
All eligibility limits calculated as a percent of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL).
1. Median value for the United States
